description: From Middle English suffisen, from Middle French souffire, from Latin sufficiō (“supply, be adequate”), from sub (“under”) + faciō (“do, make”). Cognate with French suffire.

verbs.description: suffice (third-person singular simple present suffices, present participle sufficing, simple past and past participle sufficed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be enough or sufficient; to meet the need (of anything); to be adequate; to be good enough.
examples: For this plum cake, two eggs should suffice.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To satisfy; to content; to be equal to the wants or demands of.
examples: A joint of lamb sufficed even his enormous appetite.
